prior_works.title: Computing the optimal strategy to commit to
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the leader’s optimal commitment problem and payoff in Stackelberg games; the CSG paper shows the principal can recover this same commitment value by committing to calibrated forecasts rather than directly revealing actions.

prior_works.title: Calibrated Learning and Correlated Equilibrium
prior_works.authors: Dean P. Foster, Rakesh V. Vohra
prior_works.role: Conceptual bridge between calibration and strategic best responses
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that agents best-responding to calibrated forecasts lead play toward equilibrium, directly motivating CSG’s modeling assumption that the follower best responds to calibrated predictions of the leader’s action.

prior_works.title: Asymptotic Calibration
prior_works.authors: Dean P. Foster, Rakesh V. Vohra
prior_works.role: Algorithmic foundation for calibrated forecasting against adversaries
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided constructions and guarantees for calibrated forecasters in adversarial sequences, which the CSG paper generalizes via its stronger ‘adaptive calibration’ with anytime guarantees.

prior_works.title: An analog of the minimax theorem for vector payoffs (Blackwell approachability)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Approachability is the classic machinery used to design and analyze calibration algorithms; the CSG paper’s general approach to adaptive calibration builds on this paradigm to obtain fine-grained guarantees.

prior_works.title: Bayesian Persuasion
prior_works.role: Information design lens for using forecasts as signals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Interprets forecasts as signals that shape the agent’s best response subject to Bayesian constraints; CSG leverages calibrated signals (a form of Bayes-plausible design) to induce follower actions that achieve the Stackelberg commitment value.

prior_works.title: Multicalibration: Calibration for the (Computationally-Identifiable) Masses
prior_works.authors: Yannai A. Hebert-Johnson, Michael P. Kim, Omer Reingold, Guy N. Rothblum
prior_works.role: Precursor to stronger, uniform calibration guarantees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced robust calibration that holds simultaneously over many adaptively chosen subpopulations; this spirit of robustness informs CSG’s ‘adaptive calibration’ notion with anytime, fine-grained guarantees needed for strategic interaction.

synthesis_narrative:
The core innovation of Calibrated Stackelberg Games (CSGs) is to replace direct observation of the leader’s action with calibrated forecasts and to show that, despite this informational constraint, the principal can still attain the classical Stackelberg commitment value. This rests on two intertwined pillars: Stackelberg commitment and calibrated forecasting. On the commitment side, Conitzer and Sandholm formalized computing the leader’s optimal mixed commitment; CSGs show that carefully designed forecasts can replicate the same follower responses, recovering this benchmark payoff. The information-design perspective of Kamenica–Gentzkow clarifies why: forecasts function as signals that steer the follower’s best response subject to Bayes-consistency, and calibration enforces these Bayes plausibility constraints over time.
On the forecasting side, Foster–Vohra established both the strategic relevance of calibrated forecasts—best responses to calibrated predictions lead to equilibrium—and the existence of calibrated forecasters in adversarial environments. Blackwell’s approachability provides the geometric engine behind such calibration procedures. Building on these, the CSG paper strengthens guarantees via ‘adaptive calibration,’ delivering anytime, fine-grained robustness suitable for repeated strategic interaction. Finally, ideas from multicalibration (Hebert-Johnson et al.) inform the need for calibration that holds simultaneously across adaptively revealed conditions, aligning with the paper’s uniform and adversarial guarantees. Together, these works directly shape the CSG framework, its algorithmic design for adaptive calibration, and the proof that calibrated signaling suffices to achieve optimal Stackelberg commitment utility.
